summary.seg: This manuscript contains two Greek Poems by Joshua Barnes (1654-1712), and it is in the hand of the author. A fellow of Emmanuel College from 1678, Joshua Barnes was appointed Regius Professor of Greek at the University of Cambridge in 1695. He published editions of Euripides (1694), Anacreon (1705), and Homer (1711). Being fluent in ancient Greek, which he could write and speak, from a young age Barnes composed works in Greek himself, as illustrated by the poems in this manuscript, which dates to 1673 (see J. M. Levine, The battle of the books: history and literature in the Augustan age (Ithaca and London, 1991), p. 152). Emmanuel College possesses a further manuscript of Greek poems written and copied by Barnes, of the same date: Cambridge, Emmanuel College, MS 178 .

The codex is a small volume formed of two parts, both dating to 1673, and made of the same kind of paper. In both parts the text is written perpendicular to the usual direction of the text in codices.

The first part contains the Metaphraseis, paraphrases in hexameters of Biblical texts (this text is also found in Emmanuel MS 178), followed by a few epigrams, some addressed to members of Emmanuel College, with a dedication to John Breton, its then Master. The second part contains a poem on Homer, Poematium de vatum patre et principe Homero, followed, also in this case, by some epigrams, with a dedication to James Duport, master of Magdalene College and Regius Professor of Greek.

foliation.p: Leaves have not been numbered; ff. [i]-[ii], [iii]-[iv] are later endleaves: [i]-[ii] + [1]-[32] + [iii]-[iv].
The scribe wrote running heads, with the title of the work respectively in Greek and in Latin, in the upper part of all columns.

supportDesc.condition: There are extensive water and humidity stains on the leaves in part I of the codex; parts of the external edges of ff. [1]-[6] were lost because of this and have been repaired with Japanese paper .

binding.p: Early modern western binding, paper cover, with leather over the spine and the four external corners, over millboards. Gold tooling on the spine, with title Sacra Bib. Compend., and blind tooled MS. On the spine are pasted four paper labels with the older shelfmark, MSS, 1, 3, 27. 210 155 ca. 100
binding.condition: Brown stains have spread on the paper cover near the leather parts.

history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated by Joshua Barnes to Emmanuel College (see James (1904), p. xii). On the left pastedown is pasted the College bookplate.

recordHist.source: Description (2021) partly draws on M. R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Emmanuel College (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1904), pp. 70-71.

availability.p: Visitors to Emmanuel College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Emmanuel College: Special Collections.

monogr.title: The Western manuscripts in the library of Emmanuel College: a descriptive catalogue

msItem.title: Dedication letter to John Breton (d. 1676), Master of Emmanuel College
msItem.note: On the same folio, in the lower left part, Barnes added the date on which he completed the volume Eman. Coll. Martii 28 1673 and the date of his admission to the College, 11 August 1671.

msItem.note: After the epigrams there is a note in Latin by Barnes greeting the dedicatee

support.material: Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: ff. [1]-[18] Horn in a cartouche ( ca. 65 ca. 40 ) in the gutter, comparable to Heawood Horn 2686, which is dated in 1683 (England).

collation.p: Since the quires have been sewn tightly, and were not numbered, the collation is difficult to ascertain; the observation of the watermark does not help. (It does not suggest a regular succession of quires.)

layoutDesc.layout: ff. [4]r-[18]r: The text is written perpendicular to the usual direction of the text in codices. Two columns of 26-27 lines. 140 180

handNote.p: Hand A: the texts have all been written by Barnes, Joshua, 1654-1712 Joshua Barnes , in a minuscule script, vertical, regular in size.
The text is written in brown ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. [1]r Joshua Barnes sketched in brown ink the arms of the College, a lion rampant.

additions.p: On the left pastedown is written in brown ink the previous shelfmark, 1.3.27; in pencil, in a rhombus, is written the present shelfmark, 79.

On f. [1]r, over the College arms, Barnes wrote in Greek the name of the college; under the arms he wrote a quotation from Homer, Î´ÏÏÎ¹Ï Î´â á½Î»Î¯Î³Î· ÏÎµ ÏÎ¯Î»Î· ÏÎµ ( Od. 6, 268), and a sentence in Latin.

origin.p: This part of the manuscript is an autograph by the author of the text, Joshua Barnes, and was completed on 28 March 1673 in Cambridge, Emmanuel College (see the date on f. [2]r).

support.material: Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: ff. [19]-[32] Horn in a cartouche ( ca. 65 ca. 40 ) in the gutter, comparable to Heawood Horn 2686, which is dated to 1683 (England).

collation.p: Part II consists of one single quire formed by 14 leaves.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. [22]r-[30]r: The text is written perpendicular to the usual direction of the text in codices. A single column of 22-24 lines.
ca. 130-135 ca. 80-90
ff. [32]r-[32]r: The text is written perpendicular to the usual direction of the text in codices. Two columns of 20-21 lines. ca. 130 ca. 160-170

handNote.p: Hand A: the texts have been written by Barnes, Joshua, 1654-1712 Joshua Barnes .
The text is written in a brown ink.

origin.p: This part of the manuscript is an autograph by the author of the text, Joshua Barnes, and was completed in 1673 in Cambridge, Emmanuel College (see the date on f. [32]r).
